structuralFindings.rationale: Mount Sinai has a clear hub-and-spoke model with the Hamilton and Amabel James Center for AI and Human Health serving as the central hub (65,000 sq ft, 12-story facility), with satellite teams embedded across the eight-hospital system. The Windreich Department of AI and Human Health creates central 'AI Fabric' infrastructure while distributed teams (Clinical Data Science, Digital Technology Partners) deploy to specific clinical contexts. Chief AI Officer Nadkarni explicitly advocates for 'infrastructure that spans the enterprise' with a 'hub-and-satellite model to make new tools and techniques available to all Mount Sinai physicians.'
structuralFindings.aiTeamStructure: Three-pillar structure: (1) Windreich Department of AI and Human Health - first such academic department in a US medical school, led by CAIO Girish Nadkarni, focused on research and enterprise AI infrastructure; (2) Digital Technology Partners (DTP) led by CDTO Robbie Freeman, focused on clinical deployment and patient/workforce digital products; (3) Clinical Data Science Team (created 2017) focused on real-time ML/AI for clinical intervention. The Hamilton and Amabel James Center houses ~40 Principal Investigators and 250+ graduate students, postdocs, computer scientists, and support staff. Additional specialized centers include the Center for AI in Children's Health and a digital pathology Center of Excellence (with Labcorp).

structuralFindings.investmentSignals: Hamilton and Amabel James Center is a 65,000 sq ft, 12-story facility dedicated to AI (8 of 12 floors for AI initiatives). Supported by major philanthropic gift from Hamilton 'Tony' James (Executive Vice Chairman of Blackstone) and wife Amabel. Houses ~40 Principal Investigators and 250+ staff. System has developed 17 AI products for clinical use. No specific budget or headcount figures disclosed, but scale indicates significant multi-million dollar commitment.

observableMarkers.reportingStructure: Chief AI Officer (Nadkarni) leads the academic/research AI function; Chief Digital Transformation Officer (Freeman) leads operational deployment. Both appear to report to C-suite. Merged digital and AI review structures to accelerate decision-making.
observableMarkers.resourceAllocation: Dedicated 12-story facility; philanthropic funding for research center; ring-fenced AI department with full academic resources. Experience-led model considers build/buy/partner for each use case.
observableMarkers.timeHorizons: Mixed: research function has 3-10 year horizon (fundamental AI research, genomics, drug discovery); clinical deployment has 6-24 month horizon (17 AI products deployed); immediate-term workflow improvements (NutriScan, pressure injury prediction).
observableMarkers.decisionRights: Centralized governance with distributed idea generation. Anyone can submit AI ideas through centralized intake. Risk scoring and guardrails calibrate assurance requirements to use case (lighter for back-office, heavier for clinical decision support). Always human-in-the-loop for clinical tools.
observableMarkers.metrics: Four-dimension evaluation: decision-making speed, reversibility, criticality, proximity to patient care. Also track quality ratings, reimbursement improvements (e.g., malnutrition identification 2.5-3x improvement), and documentation burden reduction (20 min per 12-hour shift).

summary: Mount Sinai Health System operates a mature Hybrid/Hub-and-Spoke AI model with the Hamilton and Amabel James Center for AI and Human Health as the central hub—a 65,000 sq ft, 12-story facility housing the first AI department at a US medical school. Chief AI Officer Girish Nadkarni leads enterprise infrastructure and research, while Chief Digital Transformation Officer Robbie Freeman leads clinical deployment. The organization emphasizes 'culture over cutting-edge models,' with centralized governance, distributed idea generation, and a human-in-the-loop philosophy for all clinical AI.
